fields: Chemistry came from the greek word "{{c2::Khemeia}}" which means {{c1::to cast together}}
What are the two properties of matter
The philosopher that introduced the idea that matter is made of indivisble particles
What did Democritus call the indivisible particles?
Whose philosophy states that all substances are made of the 4 elements
What are the 3 different domains that chemists study matter
Properties that do not depend on the amount of matter
Properties that are dependent on quantity
What is the difference between enthalpy and temperature

Temperature - Average kinetic energy of the particles in a system

Enthalpy - The total amount of kinetic energy in a system
What are the 2 main classifications of matter?
Under what classification of matter do alloys fall under?
In how many phases do homogeneous mixtures exist in?
In how many phases do heterogeneous mixtures exist in?
Defined as a mixture where all parts are distinctly visible
Defined as a heterogeneous mixture that is homogeneous to the naked eye
A method used to separate heavier components of a mixture from lighter components using wind or a current of air.[1][2]
A method for separating heavier and lighter components of a mixture using wind is called what?
What is Magnetism as a separation technique?
A process that uses a magnet to separate magnetic materials from non-magnetic materials in a mixture.[3][4]
Using a magnet to separate magnetic from non-magnetic materials is known as what?
The process where heavier, insoluble particles in a liquid settle to the bottom of a container due to gravity.[5][6][7]
The process of heavier particles settling to the bottom of a liquid is called what?
The process of carefully pouring off a liquid from a mixture after the solids have settled to the bottom, leaving the sediment behind.[8][9][10]
Carefully pouring a liquid off from settled solids is known as what?
A process where fine, suspended particles in a liquid are encouraged to clump together to form larger clusters called flocs, making them easier to separate.[11][12][13]
The process of causing fine particles to clump into larger flakes or "flocs" is known as what?
A chemical process where a substance is added to a liquid to neutralize the charge of suspended particles, causing them to destabilize and begin to clump together.[14][15]
The chemical process of neutralizing the charge of particles in a liquid to make them clump is called what?
A physical process of separating insoluble solid matter from a fluid by passing the mixture through a medium that allows the fluid to pass but retains the solid particles.[16][17][18]
A physical process for separating solids from a fluid using a porous medium is called what?
A technique used to separate a dissolved solid from a liquid by heating the solution to turn the liquid into a gas, leaving the solid component behind.[19][20][21]
The technique of separating a dissolved solid from a liquid by heating the liquid until it turns to gas is called what?
What separation methods are used for separating solids in liquid mixtures (Homogenous)
What separation methods are used for separating solids in liquid mixtures (Heterogenous)

1. Sedimentation / gravitation
2. Filtration
3. Magnetic separation
4.Fractional distillation
What separtion techniques are used to separate liquids in liquid mixtures (Homogenous)
What separtion techniques are used to separate liquids in liquid mixtures (Heterogenous)
Common techniques used for purification (for solids)
Common techniques used for purification (for liquids)
What method separates compounds in a solution with same properties?
What method separates solids or group of solids andliquids in a mixture?
What method separates solids that cannot decompose when heated in a solution?
What method separates dissolved solids in a solution?
What method separates liquids in a solution?
What method separates mixture of miscible (dissolved) liquids?
What method separates substances that sublime from two substances?
What method separates magnetic substances from non-magnetic ones?
What separation method uses solubility with ethanol to separate substances?
What separation method is based on the size of particles?
What separation method removes a liquid by heating, leaving solid behind?
“Separating and purifying the components of a mixture of two or more miscible liquids having different boiling points.”
A Change from solid to vapour without passing through liquid state
To separate sublimable compound from non–sublimable impurities
Used to separate volatile organic compounds from non volatile impurities
Obtaining solid in pure and crystalline form from its solution.
Substance is more soluble in a given solvent at higher temperature than at lower temperature
{{c1::Crystallization}} is one of the oldest purification techniques applied for solid organic compounds.
What is fractional crystallization used for?
To separate solid mixtures based on different solubilities.
It is a method used to purify an organic solid.
{{c1::Filtration}} is one of the most applied processes in organic and pharmaceutical chemistry practices.
{{c1::Gravity filtration}} is the simple form of filtration.
{{c1::Vacuum filtration}} is much faster than gravity filtration. The only difference is the employing of vacuum as a deriving force for filtration.
{{c1::Decantation}} is a process to separate mixtures by removing a liquid layer that is free of a precipitate.
{{c1::Decantation}} is a method for separating a mixture of a liquid and a heavier solid.

{{c1::Evaporation}} is a physical separation process, which removes a volatile component from a liquid solution or mixture by vaporization, obtaining a concentrated product of the nonvolatile components.
{{c1::Centrifuge}} is a device for separating particles from a solution according to there size, shape, density, viscosity of the medium.
{{c1::Centrifugation}} is a process which involves the use of the centrifugal force for the sedimentation of heterogeneous mixtures with a centrifuge.
This specific method of separation consists of successive centrifugation at increasing rotor speeds .
Liquid is converted into its vapour phase at its boiling point and vapour is then condensed back to liquid on cooling is known as {{c1::DISTILLATION}}.
{{c1::Simple distillation}} is designed to evaporate a volatile liquid from a solution of non-volatile substances; the vapor is then condensed in the water condenser and collected in the receiver.
{{c1::Separation techniques}} are used to separate mixtures into their constituent elements and/or compounds.
Examples of Ingredients derived from a natural source
Oil, Sugar, Ascorbic acid, salt, beeswax
{{c1::Mechanical separation}} is a process used typically for the heterogeneous mixture which can be separated by hand.
{{c1::Sorting}} is the simplest way to separate heterogeneous mixtures which can be done by physically separating large pieces of a mechanical mixture so that similar pieces are together.
{{c1::Magnetization or Magnetic Attraction}} is a technique that involves the separation of magnetic substances from non-magnetic substances utilizing a magnet.
The process is called {{c1::floating}} when a “lighter” component that floats on top of a liquid is skimmed or poured off.
It is called {{c1::settling}} when a “heavier” component sinks to the bottom of a liquid, and the liquid can be poured off.
A {{c1::centrifuge}} is a motor-driven laboratory apparatus.
{{c1::Centrifugation}} is a process used to speed up the settling of the precipitate.
The solid particles which are retained in the filter paper are called a {{c1::residue}}, and the clear liquid that passes through is called a {{c1::filtrate}}.
In {{c1::evaporation}}, the solvent is boiled off and escapes into the air while the solute is left behind in the holding container.
{{c1::Simple Distillation}} is a technique used to separate and collect solvent from a solution of solutes, or in a mixture of two different liquids with different boiling points by the use of heat.
{{c1::Fractional distillation}} is a process used to effectively separate a liquid mixture with a range of boiling points near each other.
What type of separation method does crude oil or petroleum products undergo?
{{c1::Paper Chromatography}} is used to separate a mixture of solutes (or liquid) with different solubility and degrees of adsorption.
What method is used for separating a mixture of dyes in ink?
What method is used for separating different types of sugars?
A {{c1::filter}} is a porous material through which the liquid can pass.
The spinning creates centripetal force that pushes the solid to the bottom, allowing the liquid (supernatant) to be poured off.
What method is used to separate blood components?

• Producing bulk drugs
  • Making biological products
  • Food processing (e.g., drying, concentrating)
  • Producing demineralized water
What are the applications of simple distillation?

• Prepares distilled water and water for injection
  • Makes aromatic and volatile waters
  • Purifies organic solvents
  • Used to make compounds like spirit of nitrous ether
  • Separates non-volatile solids from volatile liquids
Distillation involves both {{c1::evaporation}} of a liquid and {{c1::condensation}} of its vapour.
What method to use in salt dissolved in water?
What method used to separate Iron filings mixed with sand?
What separation method do masks use?
What separation method would you use in separating ?Vegetable salad (lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers)
{{c1::Accuracy}} is the condition or quality of being true,correct, or exact
{{c1::Precision}} is the extent to which a given set of measurements of the same sample agree with their mean.
the limitation of the measuring instrument
the skill of the experimenter making the measurements
{{c1::Significant Figures}} are digits in the number that are reliable and absolutely necessary to indicate the quantity of something.
{{c1::Density}} is the measurement of the amount of mass per unit of volume.
Zeros to the left of nonzero digits are {{c1::not significant}}.
Zeroes at the end of a number are significant only if they are to the {{c1::right}} of the decimal point
What is the phase change from solid to liquid?
What is the phase change from liquid to solid?
What is the phase change from gas to liquid?
What is the phase change from solid directly to gas?
What is the phase change from gas directly to solid?
process of turning sugarcane into sugar cubes
What are the three laws that Dalton based his atomic theory on?

1. Law of conservation of mass
2. Law of constant composition
3. Law of multiple proportions
What law did Antoine Lavoisier discover?
Who discovered the law of conservation of mass?
Who discovered the law of constant composition?
What law did Joseph Proust discover?
What law did John Dalton discover?
Who discovered the law of multiple proportions?
This law states that atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change
The law of conservation of mass
This law states that all samples of a pure compound contain the same elements in the same proportion
This law states that when two elements react to form more than one compound, a fixed mass of one element will react with masses of the other elements in a ratio of small, whole numbers.
What is the first part of Dalton's theory?
All matter is made of indivisible particles called atoms
What is the 2nd part of Dalton's theory
All atoms of a given element are identical in mass and properties
What is the 3rd part of Dalton's atomic theory?
Compounds are a combination of two or more different types of atoms
The {{c2::4th}} part of dalton's atomic theory states that a chemical reaction is merely a {{c1::rearrangement of atoms}}

The discovery of this concept led to the modification/debunked the 1st part of Dalton's atomic theory which states that

"All matter is made of indivisible particles called atoms"

The discovery of this concept led to the modification/debunked the 2nd part of Dalton's atomic theory which states that

"All atoms of the same element are identical"
What was John Dalton's atomic model called?
What was JJ Thompsons atomic model called?
What was Ernest Rutherford's atomic model called?
What was Niels Bohr's atomic model called?
What is Erwin Schrodinger's atomic model called?
Instead of the electron's location, the schrodinger model identifies?
The probability of finding an electron in a particular region
This model of the atom does not include subatomic particles
The "jelly" in the plum pudding model is {{c1::positively}} charged, while the "plums" are {{c1::negatively}} charged
Which experiment did Rutherford use to prove his Nuclear Atomic Model?
This model describes the atom as a small dense positively charged nucleus at the center, with electrons orbiting around it
This atomic model suggested that electrons orbit the nucleus in specific quantized energy levels/shells
This atomic model proposed the concept of orbitals
Defined as regions of probability where an electron is likely to be found
Matter can be classified according to the {{c1::phase}}, that is, the physical state a material is in.
{{c1::Elements}} are the simplest form of matter and {{c2::cannot}} be broken down using chemical methods into two or more pure substances.
{{c1::Compounds}} can be broken down into two or more pure substances.
Compounds made with only two elements (such as H2O, NO2, N2O, NaCl) are called {{c1::binary compounds}}.
The chart showing all known elements and giving some of their properties is the {{c1::Periodic Table of the Elements}}
Dalton’s model is based on a number of assumptions or “{{c1::postulates}}”.
An element is composed of particles called {{c1::atoms}}.
What is the term for transformation of pure substances into other pure substances?
Transformation of pure substances called {{c1::reactants}} into other pure substances called {{c1::products}}
Individual atoms are made of which subatomic particles?
Which subatomic particle is characterized by the symbol e-?
Which subatomic particle reside in the outer regions of a given atom
Which subatomic particle has a very small mass, me- = 9.11x10-28 grams (g)?
Which subatomic particle has a negative charge?
Which subatomic particle is characterized by the symbol p?
Which subatomic particle is reside in the central part of the atom?
Which subatomic particle has a larger mass, mp = 1.673x10-24 grams (g)?
Which subatomic particle is has a positive electric charge?
Which subatomic particle is characterized by the symbol n?
Which subatomic particle resides in the nucleus?
Which subatomic particle contain zero charge (neutral)?
Which subatomic particle has the mass of mn = 1.675x10-24 grams (g), has about the same with another subatomic particle?
Protons and neutrons are called {{c1::nucleons}} as they are all located in the {{c1::nucleus}}.
What charge is assigned to a proton when simplifying atomic charges?
A proton is assigned a charge of +1 (no unit specified).
What charge is assigned to an electron when simplifying atomic charges?
An electron is assigned a charge of –1 (no unit specified).
What is the actual charge of a proton in coulombs?
What is the actual charge of an electron in coulombs?
The number of {{c1::protons}} in the nucleus is given the name atomic number and is denoted by the symbol {{c1::Z}}.
The mass number for elements is the sum of the number of?
Atoms that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons are called {{c1::isotopes}}.
What is the name of the hydrogen isotope ²H?
What is the name of the hydrogen isotope ³H?
What is the name of the hydrogen isotope ¹H?
What stays the same in all isotopes of an element?
How many protons does every carbon isotope have?
How many neutrons does carbon-12 have?
How many neutrons does carbon-13 have?
How many neutrons does carbon-14 have?
{{c1::Molecules}} form when two or more atoms of the same or of different nonmetal elements combine with one another.
This is an aggregate of two or more atoms in a definite arrangement held together by chemical bonds
What is the net charge of molecules?
What are chemical bonds between a metal and a nonmetal.
What are chemical bonds between two nonmetals?
An {{c1::ion}} is an atom or group of atoms that has a net positive or negative charge
A {{c1::cation}} is an ion with positive charge.
An {{c1::anion}} is an ion with negative charge
If a neutral atom loses an electron or more it becomes a?
If a neutral atom gains an electron, it becomes a?
What kind of ion only has one atom?
What kind of ion has more than one atoms?
When an atom loses or gains electrons, an {{c1::ion}} is formed.
What kind of molecule has only two atoms?
What kind of molecule has more than two atoms?
Elements in the Periodic Table can be classified as? (3)
Metals are typically on the _____ side of the Periodic Table with an exception of which element?
Nonmetals are typically on the {{c1::right- hand}} side of the Periodic Table
Metalloids on either side of a stairway between metals and nonmetals starting between {{c1::Boron}} and {{c1::Aluminum}}.
Metals are characterized by which physical properties?

1. Luster
2. High heat
3. electrical conductivity
4. Malleability
5. Ductility
The horizontal rows in the Periodic Table are called {{c1::periods}}.
The vertical columns in the Periodic Table are called {{c1::groups}}.
There are {{c1::18}} groups and {{c1::7}} periods in the Periodic Table.
Some of the groups and some sets of groups have specific names and constitute {{c1::families}}.
Elements in groups 1, 2, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 are called {{c1::main group elements}}.
What are elements in groups 3 through 12 are called?
What are the elements in group 1, except hydrogen, are called?
The elements in group 2 are called?
What are the elements in group 17 called?
The elements in group 18 are called?
Group 1 elements (Li, Na, K, etc...) tend to lose how many electrons?
Group 2 elements (Be, Mg, Ca, Ba, etc...) tend to lose {{c1::2}} electrons.
Group 13 metals (Al, Ga, In) tend to lose {{c1::3}} electrons.
Group 15 nonmetals tend to gain {{c1::3}} electrons.
Group 16 nonmetals tend to gain {{c1::2}} electrons.
Group 17 nonmetals (halogens) tend to gain {{c1::1}} electron, forming {{c1::halides}}.
Group 18 (noble gases) {{c1::do not}}  form stable ions
Why don’t noble gases (Group 18) form stable ions?
Because they are inert — their outer electron shells are already full.

{{c1::Stable ions}} are often formed through a gain or a loss of electrons that is such that the resulting ions have the same number of electrons as the closest noble gas element in the Periodic Table.
When elements such as H, N, O, F, Cl aren't stable in their elemental forms, they exists as what?
When elements such as H, N, O, F, Cl are in their "molecular form", what do their formula/symbols look like?
These two elements are not stable in their element form and exist as liquids in the molecular form

How many atoms are there in a single stable molecular form of sulfur?

In what series of polyatomic ions do we use the prefixes "per-" and "hypo-"
Anions made using halogens and oxygen
Name these ions from top to bottom
These are covalent compounds that have a net charge

which is named first?

SO3 = monosulfur trioxide.

What is wrong about this?
if the first element in a binary molecular compound only has one atom, then there should be no prefix
What is thte special rule for naming binary hydrogen compounds

NO greek prefix is used

e.g. H2S is hydrogen sulfide, not dihydrogen sulfide
What is the special rule for binary hydrogen compounds with group 15 non-metals?
The group 15 non-metal is written  first in the formula
Given that phosphorous is a group 15 non-metal, how would you write the molecular formula of a binary hydrogen compound with 3 hydrogen atoms, and 1 phosphorous atom
How are binary molecular compounds with phosphorous named given that phosphorous exhibits multiple oxidation states?

Oxides of phosphorous are often named assuming phosphorous was a metal

e.g. 

phosphorous (V) oxide
What are the 2 components in a chemical reaction?
What does the arrow mean in a chemical reaction?
It is the quantity of matter contained in a form of an element measured in amu.
What is the unit for atomic mass?
This is a given mass of a given compound or molecule
12 amu (C) → Atomic mass or Molecular mass?
Atomic mass (mass of a single carbon atom)
H2​O=18 amu → Atomic mass or Molecular mass?
Molecular mass (sum of atomic masses of H and O in water)
This involves using relationships between reactants and/or products in a chemical reaction to determine desired quantitative data.
Stoichiometry is deried from the Greek words, "{{c1::stoikhein}}" meaning {{c2::element}} and "{{c1::metron}}" meaning {{c3::measure}}.
{{c1::Stoichiometry}}, when translated from Greek, literally means the {{c2::measure of elements}}
{{c1::A mole}} can be used to quantify number of atoms or numbers of molecules.
A mole is equivalent to Avogadro's number of particles equal to {{c1::6.02 x 10^23}}
A {{c1::mole}} is similar to a pair which means 2, and a dozen that means 12
What is the unit for mole?
What is the unit for molar mass?
Why is the mass–mole relationship important in chemistry?
It links the macroscopic world (mass we measure) to the microscopic world (atoms/molecules).
{{c1::Reactants}} appear on the left side of the equation.
{{c1::Products}} appear on the right side of the equation.
The states of the reactants and products are written in {{c1::parentheses}} to the {{c1::right}} of each compound.
{{c1::Coefficients}} are inserted to balance the equation.
{{c1::Subscripts}} tell the number of atoms of each element in a molecule
This type of reaction invovles two or more substances react to form one product
This type of reactions includes one substance breaks down into two or more substances
A rapid reaction with oxygen that often produces a flame, usually forming CO₂ and H₂O.
Most often involve hydrocarbons reacting with oxygen in the air to produce {{c1::CO2}} and {{c1::H2O}}.
Defined (since 1961) as: 1/12 mass of the 12C isotope.
Sum of the atomic weights for the atoms in a chemical formula
Sum of the atomic weights of the atoms in a molecule
How many particles are in one mole of atoms, ions, or molecules?
How many atoms or ions are in one mole of a compound?
Avogadro’s number × atoms/ions per molecule or formula unit
1 mole of any substance has the same number of molecules. T or F?
The number of moles correspond to the number of molecules. T or F?
What does percent composition tell us?
The percentage of a compound’s mass that comes from each element.
